trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure Data Factory pipeline with a Copy Activity by using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure Data Factory pipeline with a Copy Activity by using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Create and monitor a data factory using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Create and monitor a data factory using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Tutorial Overview
trans-unit.target: Tutorial Overview

trans-unit.source: Using Data Factory Editor
trans-unit.target: Using Data Factory Editor

trans-unit.source: Using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Using Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Using Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: The [Get started with Azure Data Factory][adf-get-started] tutorial shows you how to create and monitor an Azure data factory using the [Azure Preview Portal][azure-preview-portal].
trans-unit.target: The [Get started with Azure Data Factory][adf-get-started] tutorial shows you how to create and monitor an Azure data factory using the [Azure Preview Portal][azure-preview-portal].

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create and monitor an Azure data factory by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create and monitor an Azure data factory by using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: The pipeline in the data factory you create in this tutorial copies data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The pipeline in the data factory you create in this tutorial copies data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This article does not cover all the Data Factory cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This article does not cover all the Data Factory cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: See [Data Factory Cmdlet Reference][cmdlet-reference] for comprehensive documentation on Data Factory cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: See [Data Factory Cmdlet Reference][cmdlet-reference] for comprehensive documentation on Data Factory cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Apart from prerequisites listed in the Tutorial Overview topic, you need to have Azure PowerShell installed on your computer.
trans-unit.target: Apart from prerequisites listed in the Tutorial Overview topic, you need to have Azure PowerShell installed on your computer.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have it already, download and install [Azure PowerShell][download-azure-powershell] on your computer.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have it already, download and install [Azure PowerShell][download-azure-powershell] on your computer.

trans-unit.source: In This Tutorial
trans-unit.target: In This Tutorial

trans-unit.source: The following table lists the steps you will perform as part of the tutorial and their descriptions.
trans-unit.target: The following table lists the steps you will perform as part of the tutorial and their descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Step
trans-unit.target: Step

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create an Azure data factory named **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create an Azure data factory named **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create linked services
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create linked services

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create two linked services: **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService**.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create two linked services: **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService**.

trans-unit.source: The StorageLinkedService links an Azure storage and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH.
trans-unit.target: The StorageLinkedService links an Azure storage and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create input and output datasets
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create input and output datasets

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will define two data sets (**EmpTableFromBlob** and **EmpSQLTable**) that are used as input and output tables for the **Copy Activity** in the ADFTutorialPipeline that you will create in the next step.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will define two data sets (**EmpTableFromBlob** and **EmpSQLTable**) that are used as input and output tables for the **Copy Activity** in the ADFTutorialPipeline that you will create in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create a pipeline named **ADFTutorialPipeline** in the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create a pipeline named **ADFTutorialPipeline** in the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: The pipeline will have a **Copy Activity** that copies data from an Azure blob to an output Azure database table.
trans-unit.target: The pipeline will have a **Copy Activity** that copies data from an Azure blob to an output Azure database table.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Monitor data sets and pipeline
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Monitor data sets and pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will monitor the datasets and the pipeline using Azure PowerShell in this step.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will monitor the datasets and the pipeline using Azure PowerShell in this step.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory

trans-unit.source: In this step, you use the Azure PowerShell to create an Azure data factory named **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you use the Azure PowerShell to create an Azure data factory named **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: Launch **Azure PowerShell** and execute the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Launch **Azure PowerShell** and execute the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Keep the Azure PowerShell open until the end of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Keep the Azure PowerShell open until the end of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you close and reopen, you need to run these commands again.
trans-unit.target: If you close and reopen, you need to run these commands again.

trans-unit.source: Run **Add-AzureAccount** and enter the user name and password that you use to sign-in to the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Run **Add-AzureAccount** and enter the user name and password that you use to sign-in to the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Run **Get-AzureSubscription** to view all the subscriptions for this account.
trans-unit.target: Run **Get-AzureSubscription** to view all the subscriptions for this account.

trans-unit.source: Run **Select-AzureSubscription** to select the subscription that you want to work with.
trans-unit.target: Run **Select-AzureSubscription** to select the subscription that you want to work with.

trans-unit.source: This subscription should be the same as the one you used in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: This subscription should be the same as the one you used in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Switch to **AzureResourceManager** mode as the Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in this mode.
trans-unit.target: Switch to **AzureResourceManager** mode as the Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in this mode.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure resource group named: **ADFTutorialResourceGroup** by running the following command.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure resource group named: **ADFTutorialResourceGroup** by running the following command.

trans-unit.source: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the resource group named **ADFTutorialResourceGroup**.
trans-unit.target: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the resource group named **ADFTutorialResourceGroup**.

trans-unit.source: If you use a different resource group, you will need to use it in place of ADFTutorialResourceGroup in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you use a different resource group, you will need to use it in place of ADFTutorialResourceGroup in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Run the **New-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet to create a data factory named: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: Run the **New-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet to create a data factory named: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.
trans-unit.target: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.

trans-unit.source: If you receive the error: **Data factory name “ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH” is not available**, change the name (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH).
trans-unit.target: If you receive the error: **Data factory name “ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH” is not available**, change the name (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH).

trans-unit.source: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactoryPSH while performing steps in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactoryPSH while performing steps in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create linked services
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create linked services

trans-unit.source: Linked services link data stores or compute services to an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: Linked services link data stores or compute services to an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: A data store can be an Azure Storage, Azure SQL Database or an on-premises SQL Server database that contains input data or stores output data for a Data Factory pipeline.
trans-unit.target: A data store can be an Azure Storage, Azure SQL Database or an on-premises SQL Server database that contains input data or stores output data for a Data Factory pipeline.

trans-unit.source: A compute service is the service that processes input data and produces output data.
trans-unit.target: A compute service is the service that processes input data and produces output data.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create two linked services: **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService**.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create two linked services: **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService**.

trans-unit.source: StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure Storage Account and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure Storage Account and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: You will create a pipeline later in this tutorial that copies data from a blob container in StorageLinkedService to a SQL table in AzureSqlLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: You will create a pipeline later in this tutorial that copies data from a blob container in StorageLinkedService to a SQL table in AzureSqlLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service for an Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service for an Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named **StorageLinkedService.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** with the following content.
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named **StorageLinkedService.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** with the following content.

trans-unit.source: Create the folder ADFGetStartedPSH if it does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: Create the folder ADFGetStartedPSH if it does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: Replace **accountname** with the name of your storage account and **accountkey** with the key for your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace **accountname** with the name of your storage account and **accountkey** with the key for your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: In the **Azure PowerShell**, switch to the **ADFGetStartedPSH** folder.
trans-unit.target: In the **Azure PowerShell**, switch to the **ADFGetStartedPSH** folder.

trans-unit.source: You can use the **New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService** cmdlet to create a linked service.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService** cmdlet to create a linked service.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet and other Data Factory cmdlets you use in this tutorial require you to pass values for the **ResourceGroupName** and **DataFactoryName** parameters.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet and other Data Factory cmdlets you use in this tutorial require you to pass values for the **ResourceGroupName** and **DataFactoryName** parameters.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use **Get-AzureDataFactory** to get a DataFactory object and pass the object without typing ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName each time you run a cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use **Get-AzureDataFactory** to get a DataFactory object and pass the object without typing ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName each time you run a cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to assign the output of the **Get-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet to a variable: **$df**.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to assign the output of the **Get-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet to a variable: **$df**.

trans-unit.source: Now, run the **New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService** cmdlet to create the linked service: **StorageLinkedService**.
trans-unit.target: Now, run the **New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService** cmdlet to create the linked service: **StorageLinkedService**.

trans-unit.source: If you hadn't run the **Get-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet and assigned the output to **$df** variable, you would have to specify values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters as follows.
trans-unit.target: If you hadn't run the **Get-AzureDataFactory** cmdlet and assigned the output to **$df** variable, you would have to specify values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters as follows.

trans-unit.source: If you close the Azure PowerShell in the middle of the tutorial, you will have run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet next time you launch Azure PowerShell to complete the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you close the Azure PowerShell in the middle of the tutorial, you will have run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet next time you launch Azure PowerShell to complete the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service for an Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service for an Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named AzureSqlLinkedService.json with the following content.
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named AzureSqlLinkedService.json with the following content.

trans-unit.source: Replace **servername**, **databasename**, **username@servername**, and **password** with names of your Azure SQL server, database, user account, and password.
trans-unit.target: Replace **servername**, **databasename**, **username@servername**, and **password** with names of your Azure SQL server, database, user account, and password.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create a linked service.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create a linked service.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that the **Allow access to Azure services** setting is turned ON for your Azure SQL server.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that the **Allow access to Azure services** setting is turned ON for your Azure SQL server.

trans-unit.source: To verify and turn it on, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To verify and turn it on, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click **BROWSE** hub on the left and click **SQL servers**.
trans-unit.target: Click **BROWSE** hub on the left and click **SQL servers**.

trans-unit.source: Select your server, and click **SETTINGS** on the SQL SERVER blade.
trans-unit.target: Select your server, and click **SETTINGS** on the SQL SERVER blade.

trans-unit.source: In the **SETTINGS** blade, click **Firewall**.
trans-unit.target: In the **SETTINGS** blade, click **Firewall**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Firewalll settings** blade, click **ON** for **Allow access to Azure services**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Firewalll settings** blade, click **ON** for **Allow access to Azure services**.

trans-unit.source: Click **ACTIVE** hub on the left to switch to the **Data Factory** blade you were on.
trans-unit.target: Click **ACTIVE** hub on the left to switch to the **Data Factory** blade you were on.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create input and output tables
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create input and output tables

trans-unit.source: In the previous step, you created linked services **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService** to link an Azure Storage account and Azure SQL database to the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.
trans-unit.target: In the previous step, you created linked services **StorageLinkedService** and **AzureSqlLinkedService** to link an Azure Storage account and Azure SQL database to the data factory: **ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH**.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create tables that represent the input and output data for the Copy Activity in the pipeline you will be creating in the next step.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create tables that represent the input and output data for the Copy Activity in the pipeline you will be creating in the next step.

trans-unit.source: A table is a rectangular dataset and it is the only type of dataset that is supported at this time.
trans-unit.target: A table is a rectangular dataset and it is the only type of dataset that is supported at this time.

trans-unit.source: The input table in this tutorial refers to a blob container in the Azure Storage that StorageLinkedService points to and the output table refers to a SQL table in the Azure SQL database that AzureSqlLinkedService points to.
trans-unit.target: The input table in this tutorial refers to a blob container in the Azure Storage that StorageLinkedService points to and the output table refers to a SQL table in the Azure SQL database that AzureSqlLinkedService points to.

trans-unit.source: Prepare Azure Blob Storage and Azure SQL Database for the tutorial
trans-unit.target: Prepare Azure Blob Storage and Azure SQL Database for the tutorial

trans-unit.source: Skip this step if you have gone through the tutorial from [Get started with Azure Data Factory][adf-get-started] article.
trans-unit.target: Skip this step if you have gone through the tutorial from [Get started with Azure Data Factory][adf-get-started] article.

trans-unit.source: You need to perform the following steps to prepare the Azure blob storage and Azure SQL database for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You need to perform the following steps to prepare the Azure blob storage and Azure SQL database for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Create a blob container named **adftutorial** in the Azure blob storage that **StorageLinkedService** points to.
trans-unit.target: Create a blob container named **adftutorial** in the Azure blob storage that **StorageLinkedService** points to.

trans-unit.source: Create and upload a text file, **emp.txt**, as a blob to the **adftutorial** container.
trans-unit.target: Create and upload a text file, **emp.txt**, as a blob to the **adftutorial** container.

trans-unit.source: Create a table named **emp** in the Azure SQL Database in the Azure SQL database that **AzureSqlLinkedService** points to.
trans-unit.target: Create a table named **emp** in the Azure SQL Database in the Azure SQL database that **AzureSqlLinkedService** points to.

trans-unit.source: Launch Notepad, paste the following text, and save it as **emp.txt** to **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder on your hard drive.
trans-unit.target: Launch Notepad, paste the following text, and save it as **emp.txt** to **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder on your hard drive.

trans-unit.source: Use tools such as [Azure Storage Explorer](https://azurestorageexplorer.codeplex.com/) to create the **adftutorial** container and to upload the **emp.txt** file to the container.
trans-unit.target: Use tools such as [Azure Storage Explorer](https://azurestorageexplorer.codeplex.com/) to create the **adftutorial** container and to upload the **emp.txt** file to the container.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Explorer
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Explorer

trans-unit.source: Use the following SQL script to create the **emp** table in your Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Use the following SQL script to create the **emp** table in your Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Create input table
trans-unit.target: Create input table

trans-unit.source: A table is a rectangular dataset and has a schema.
trans-unit.target: A table is a rectangular dataset and has a schema.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create a table named **EmpBlobTable** that points to a blob container in the Azure Storage represented by the **StorageLinkedService** linked service.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create a table named **EmpBlobTable** that points to a blob container in the Azure Storage represented by the **StorageLinkedService** linked service.

trans-unit.source: This blob container (**adftutorial**) contains the input data in the file: **emp.txt**.
trans-unit.target: This blob container (**adftutorial**) contains the input data in the file: **emp.txt**.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named **EmpBlobTable.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content:
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named **EmpBlobTable.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: dataset **type** is set to **AzureBlob**.
trans-unit.target: dataset **type** is set to **AzureBlob**.

trans-unit.source: **linkedServiceName** is set to **StorageLinkedService**.
trans-unit.target: **linkedServiceName** is set to **StorageLinkedService**.

trans-unit.source: **folderPath** is set to the **adftutorial** container.
trans-unit.target: **folderPath** is set to the **adftutorial** container.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify the name of a blob within the folder.
trans-unit.target: You can also specify the name of a blob within the folder.

trans-unit.source: Since you are not specifying the name of the blob, data from all blobs in the container is considered as an input data.
trans-unit.target: Since you are not specifying the name of the blob, data from all blobs in the container is considered as an input data.

trans-unit.source: format **type** is set to **TextFormat**
trans-unit.target: format **type** is set to **TextFormat**

trans-unit.source: There are two fields in the text file – **FirstName** and **LastName** – separated by a comma character (**columnDelimiter**)
trans-unit.target: There are two fields in the text file – **FirstName** and **LastName** – separated by a comma character (**columnDelimiter**)

trans-unit.source: The **availability** is set to **hourly** (**frequency** is set to **hour** and **interval** is set to **1** ), so the Data Factory service will look for input data every hour in the root folder in the blob container (**adftutorial**) you specified.
trans-unit.target: The **availability** is set to **hourly** (**frequency** is set to **hour** and **interval** is set to **1** ), so the Data Factory service will look for input data every hour in the root folder in the blob container (**adftutorial**) you specified.

trans-unit.source: if you don't specify a **fileName** for an **input** **table**, all files/blobs from the input folder (**folderPath**) are considered as inputs.
trans-unit.target: if you don't specify a **fileName** for an **input** **table**, all files/blobs from the input folder (**folderPath**) are considered as inputs.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.

trans-unit.source: See the sample files in the [tutorial][adf-tutorial] for examples.
trans-unit.target: See the sample files in the [tutorial][adf-tutorial] for examples.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a **fileName** for an **output table**, the generated files in the **folderPath** are named in the following format: Data.<Guid\>.txt (example: Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a **fileName** for an **output table**, the generated files in the **folderPath** are named in the following format: Data.<Guid\>.txt (example: Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).

trans-unit.source: To set **folderPath** and **fileName** dynamically based on the **SliceStart** time, use the **partitionedBy** property.
trans-unit.target: To set **folderPath** and **fileName** dynamically based on the **SliceStart** time, use the **partitionedBy** property.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.

trans-unit.source: See [JSON Scripting Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=516971) for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See [JSON Scripting Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=516971) for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: Create output table
trans-unit.target: Create output table

trans-unit.source: In this part of the step, you will create an output table named **EmpSQLTable** that points to a SQL table (**emp**) in the Azure SQL database that is represented by the **AzureSqlLinkedService** linked service.
trans-unit.target: In this part of the step, you will create an output table named **EmpSQLTable** that points to a SQL table (**emp**) in the Azure SQL database that is represented by the **AzureSqlLinkedService** linked service.

trans-unit.source: The pipeline copies data from the input blob to the **emp** table.
trans-unit.target: The pipeline copies data from the input blob to the **emp** table.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named **EmpSQLTable.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content.
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named **EmpSQLTable.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content.

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: dataset **type** is set to **AzureSqlTable**.
trans-unit.target: dataset **type** is set to **AzureSqlTable**.

trans-unit.source: **linkedServiceName** is set to **AzureSqlLinkedService**.
trans-unit.target: **linkedServiceName** is set to **AzureSqlLinkedService**.

trans-unit.source: **tablename** is set to **emp**.
trans-unit.target: **tablename** is set to **emp**.

trans-unit.source: There are three columns – **ID**, **FirstName**, and **LastName** – in the emp table in the database, but ID is an identity column, so you need to specify only **FirstName** and **LastName** here.
trans-unit.target: There are three columns – **ID**, **FirstName**, and **LastName** – in the emp table in the database, but ID is an identity column, so you need to specify only **FirstName** and **LastName** here.

trans-unit.source: The **availability** is set to **hourly** (**frequency** set to **hour** and **interval** set to **1**).
trans-unit.target: The **availability** is set to **hourly** (**frequency** set to **hour** and **interval** set to **1**).

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the **emp** table in the Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the **emp** table in the Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create and run a pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you create a pipeline with a **Copy Activity** that uses **EmpTableFromBlob** as input and **EmpSQLTable** as output.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you create a pipeline with a **Copy Activity** that uses **EmpTableFromBlob** as input and **EmpSQLTable** as output.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named **ADFTutorialPipeline.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content:
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named **ADFTutorialPipeline.json** in the **C:\ADFGetStartedPSH** folder with the following content:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: In the activities section, there is only one activity whose **type** is set to **Copy**.
trans-unit.target: In the activities section, there is only one activity whose **type** is set to **Copy**.

trans-unit.source: Input for the activity is set to **EmpTableFromBlob** and output for the activity is set to **EmpSQLTable**.
trans-unit.target: Input for the activity is set to **EmpTableFromBlob** and output for the activity is set to **EmpSQLTable**.

trans-unit.source: In the **transformation** section, **BlobSource** is specified as the source type and **SqlSink** is specified as the sink type.
trans-unit.target: In the **transformation** section, **BlobSource** is specified as the source type and **SqlSink** is specified as the sink type.

trans-unit.source: Replace the value of the **start** property with the current day and **end** value with the next day.
trans-unit.target: Replace the value of the **start** property with the current day and **end** value with the next day.

trans-unit.source: Both start and end datetimes must be in [ISO format](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601).
trans-unit.target: Both start and end datetimes must be in [ISO format](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601).

trans-unit.source: The **end** time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The **end** time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify value for the **end** property, it is calculated as "**start + 48 hours**".
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify value for the **end** property, it is calculated as "**start + 48 hours**".

trans-unit.source: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify **9/9/9999** as the value for the **end** property.
trans-unit.target: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify **9/9/9999** as the value for the **end** property.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.

trans-unit.source: See [JSON Scripting Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=516971) for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See [JSON Scripting Reference](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=516971) for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: **Congratulations!** You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: **Congratulations!** You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipeline
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will use the Azure PowerShell to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will use the Azure PowerShell to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: Run **Get-AzureDataFactory** and assign the output to a variable $df.
trans-unit.target: Run **Get-AzureDataFactory** and assign the output to a variable $df.

trans-unit.source: Run **Get-AzureDataFactorySlice** to get details about all slices of the **EmpSQLTable**, which is the output table of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Run **Get-AzureDataFactorySlice** to get details about all slices of the **EmpSQLTable**, which is the output table of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Replace year, month, and date part of the **StartDateTime** parameter with the current year, month, and date.
trans-unit.target: Replace year, month, and date part of the **StartDateTime** parameter with the current year, month, and date.

trans-unit.source: This should match the **Start** value in the pipeline JSON.
trans-unit.target: This should match the **Start** value in the pipeline JSON.

trans-unit.source: You should see 24 slices, one for each hour from 12 AM of the current day to 12 AM of the next day.
trans-unit.target: You should see 24 slices, one for each hour from 12 AM of the current day to 12 AM of the next day.

trans-unit.source: First slice:
trans-unit.target: First slice:

trans-unit.source: Last slice:
trans-unit.target: Last slice:

trans-unit.source: Run **Get-AzureDataFactoryRun** to get the details of activity runs for a **specific** slice.
trans-unit.target: Run **Get-AzureDataFactoryRun** to get the details of activity runs for a **specific** slice.

trans-unit.source: Change the value of the **StartDateTime** parameter to match the **Start** time of the slice from the output above.
trans-unit.target: Change the value of the **StartDateTime** parameter to match the **Start** time of the slice from the output above.

trans-unit.source: The value of the **StartDateTime** must be in [ISO format](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601).
trans-unit.target: The value of the **StartDateTime** must be in [ISO format](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601).

trans-unit.target: You should see output similar to the following:
